articles.title: UN chief says world should not be intimidated by Israel
articles.author: Amélie BOTTOLLIER-DEPOIS AFP
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres says the world should not be intimidated by Israel and its annexation of the occupied West Bank. He also calls for more ambitious climate action, saying efforts to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius are at risk of "collapsing".

articles.title: Video: 1.5C warming goal at risk of ‚collapsing‘: UN chief
articles.author: glomex.com
articles.summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres says efforts to cap climate warming at 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels are failing. UN is preparing to host a climate week event alongside its annual diplomatic gathering this year. He says the objective is on the verge of collapsing.

articles.title: Widow's £1 Million Home Faces Demolition as Sea Eats Away at Clifftop
articles.author: Daily Mail UK
articles.summary: Jean Flick's home in Thorpeness, Suffolk, is at risk of being demolished due to coastal erosion. She has lived in the seaside property for 25 years and hopes the tide won't reach the edge of the cliff and she won't have to leave her home.

articles.title: UN chief warns 1.5C warming goal at risk of 'collapsing'
articles.author: Amélie BOTTOLLIER-DEPOIS
articles.summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres says efforts to cap climate warming at 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial level are failing. UN prepared to host a climate week event alongside its annual diplomatic gathering. UN hopes that the climate summit co-chaired Wednesday in New York will be an opportunity to breathe life into efforts ahead of COP30.

articles.title: UN chief warns 1.5C warming goal at risk of 'collapsing'
articles.author: Amélie Bottollier-Depois Afp
articles.summary: Guterres is concerned that national climate action plans may not support the goal of limiting global warming. He is concerned about Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCCs) and their support for the climate action plan's goals.      Â

articles.title: Brewing cotton crisis
articles.author: editorial
articles.summary: Cotton farmers and related industries are facing another crisis year. Extreme weather events, including heatwaves, torrential rains and catastrophic floods, and the spread of cotton leaf curl virus have placed Pakistan's most important cash crop under severe threat. Experts warn that production losses could reach 0.6 to 1 million bales due to the recent floods alone, and national output may plummet to below 5 million. Farmers in southern Punjab districts, such as Jalalpur Pirwala, Alipur and Lodhran, have suffered extensive damage.

articles.title: Forget climate pledges, just act
articles.author: Wanjira Mathai
articles.summary: This month, countries are expected to submit their Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) (their official climate action plans), so progress can be assessed before COP30 in Belém this November. Many countries have ignored or watered down their NDCs. Africa's NDC highlights sectors such as forestry, yet our forests remain under constant threat.

articles.title: The death of common sense
articles.author: Hui Jin
articles.summary: Common Sense died in Australia from heart failure at the beginning of the new millennium. Andrew Hastie threatens to resign from the Liberal Party if they don't abandon the pursuit of net zero. China, India and the US are the world's biggest carbon emitters. Australia exports six times more coal than it uses and four times as much gas as it uses.

articles.title: Newsom signs climate overhaul, extending cap and trade while boosting oil drilling
articles.author: Jeanne Kuang
articles.summary: Rich Pedroncelli is an expert on climate change and the environment. He works for Associated Press. He is based in Rome, Italy. He also works for Climate and Environment magazine.    in the U.S. and in Italy, he is a professor.

articles.title: Flash droughts and erosion: how climate volatility is affecting the Hunter
articles.author: Matthew Kelly
articles.summary: Flash droughts like the one that struck the Upper Hunter in 2023 are likely to increase as the region's climate becomes more volatile. The report predicts sea level rise could put 1.5 million more people in high-risk coastal areas by 2050. Property value losses could reach $611 billion by 2050 as climate change intensifies.

articles.title: Flash droughts and erosion: how climate volatility is affecting the Hunter
articles.author: Matthew Kelly
articles.summary: 'Flash droughts', such as the one that struck the Upper Hunter in 2023, are likely to increase as the region's climate becomes more volatile, climate scientists have warned, as a result of changes in the climate. The Upper Hunter was hit by a flash drought.

articles.title: Flash droughts and erosion: how climate volatility is affecting the Hunter
articles.author: Matthew Kelly
articles.summary: 'Flash droughts', such as the one that struck the Upper Hunter in 2023, are likely to increase as the region's climate becomes more volatile, according to climate scientists. Tributes & Funerals Notices are as follows:Capon, Denise Lynette, Wood, Sydney Charles, Nicholson, Judith Leanne, and Burke, Myrtle Catherine.

articles.title: 'Complete trainwreck!' Trump official explodes at Al Gore during bizarre Fox meltdown
articles.author: Daniel Hampton
articles.summary: Chris Wright joined Maria Bartiromo on her show "Mornings with Maria" on Friday. He was asked what he would tell Al Gore and the skeptics about climate change ahead of his appearance at an upcoming New York Times Climate Forward event scheduled for Sept. 24. Wright blasted Al Gore's "nonsense" that put the United States in a bad position.

articles.title: Louisiana reports five deaths from flesh-eating bacteria found in coastal waters
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: 5 people in Louisiana have died in 2025 from Vibrio vulnificus, which is a flesh-eating bacteria found in warm coastal waters. There is a warning over climate-linked increase of such cases in the state due to warmer seas.

articles.title: Researchers urge 'Lights Out' as 12.3M birds to migrate over Washington state this weekend
articles.author: Ashley Ruiz
articles.summary: Millions of migrating birds will cross Washington state on the night of September 18-19. Researchers at BirdCast and Purdue University's AeroEco Lab use radar, atmospheric data and modeling, historical records, and many other tools to study bird migration. One of the biggest threats to migrating birds is artificial light. Scientists encourage people to turn off or dim the lights between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m., during critical migration periods.

articles.title: Warning parts of Australia on track to become 'unliveable'
articles.summary: Parts of northern Australia will be unliveable within decades if more is not done to cut carbon emissions, an environmental conference has been told. The first National Climate Risk Assessment painted a catastrophic vision of Australia's future if global warming goes unchecked. The federal government's 2035 climate target aims to bring emissions down by between 62 and 70 per cent in the next decade, based on 2005 levels. Dr Howey is disappointed with the Albanese government's target.

articles.title: From Science to Global Action: Safeguarding our Ozone for the Next Generation
articles.author: Akosua Aninakwa
articles.summary: The 2025 theme for International Day for the Preservation of the Ozone Layer, 'From Science to Global Action', underscores the urgency of moving beyond research to accelerated action in tackling one of humanity's most pressing contemporary challenges. The Montreal Protocol in 1987 marked a pivotal moment in global environmental action. It bridged the gap between scientific research and concrete global action at a time of rapid technological advancement and mounting environmental challenges.

articles.title: The Climate CO2 Hoax – What ChatGPT Won't Tell You
articles.author: Reality Books
articles.summary: ChatGPT is a computer program that claims to be a reliable source of information about climate change. It claims that there is a large-scale consensus between CO2 emissions and global average temperature increases. This consensus is supported by numerous scientific organizations, including the US National Academy of Sciences, the American Geophysical Union, and the Royal Society of the United Kingdom.

articles.title: Increasing Pakistan's Climate Resilience
articles.author: Sajid Salamat
articles.summary: Human-induced climate change is one of the biggest enemies of Pakistan. According to the GermanWatch's Climate Risk Index 2025, Pakistan suffered the most due to the negative impacts of extreme weather events in 2022. Pakistan is expected to lose at least 18 – 20% of its gross domestic product (GDP) by 2050 due to severe climate-related incidents, environmental deterioration and air pollution. Pakistan's cities would be the battleground in the fight against climate change. Bhungroo is a water management technique that injects and stores excess rainfall underground and takes it out for use in dry spells.

articles.title: Watch energy secretary melt down over climate change
articles.author: Walter Einenkel
articles.summary: Energy Secretary Chris Wright appeared on Fox Business Friday. He blamed Al Gore for 'peddling climate change nonsense' and promoted his own nonsensical belief that climate change does not exist. According to NASA, the amount of Arctic sea ice has continued its downward trend since scientists began tracking it in 1979.

articles.title: Climate change and child labour
articles.author: Anniversary Issue-I
articles.summary: Bangladesh is not on track to eliminate child labour by 2025, with a child labour rate of 4.4% in 2022. Most of these children work in informal sectors under hazardous conditions, facing health risks, exploitation, and limited prospects for education. Climate-induced disasters degrade livelihoods, displace communities, and push children into labour. Climate adaptation funding rarely integrates child protection measures.

articles.title: Climate risks report paints grim picture, but expert on societal collapse explains giving up is not the answer
articles.author: Jess Davis
articles.summary: Luke Kemp is a researcher at the Centre for the Study of Existential Risk at the University of Cambridge. He studies the study of past civilisational collapses and what they can tell us about the future. Climate change is one of the most important drivers of his research. The national climate risk assessment released by the federal government this week details how climate change will impact the country out to the end of the century.

articles.title: 'Soil Testing Day' in Altadena aims to make post-fire detection easy and accessible
articles.author: Josie Huang
articles.summary: Climate and Environment is a topic for this article. For more information, go to: http://www.cnn.com/en/news/environmental-topics/climate-and-environmental/story/story-link/cnn-en.

articles.title: NASA warns of solar storm chaos as sunâs unexpected awakening threatens global blackouts
articles.author: Natural News
articles.summary: NASA is warning of stronger solar winds, flares and geomagnetic storms on the sun. The sun has recently experienced a resurgence in activity after a decades-long decline in activity. NASA has issued a warning about the possibility of solar flares and solar winds.

articles.title: Matt Kean on Australia's future in a climate crisis
articles.author: Adam Morton
articles.summary: The Albanese government has a target of a 62-70% emissions cut by 2035 compared to 2005 levels. It comes after the release of the national climate risk assessment. Adam Morton speaks to the chair of the Climate Change Authority, Matt Kean, on the advice that informed the government's emissions reduction target for 2035.

articles.title: Indonesia Climate Rally
articles.author: 주식농사왕의 농사매매
articles.summary: Indonesia Climate Rally called for leaders to take action to prevent global climate crisis in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Friday, Sept. 19, 2025. Environmental activists paraded a snake effigy during the rally calling for action on climate change in Jakarta.

articles.title: Oregonians are asked to turn off their lights tonight. This is why
articles.author: Karly Imus
articles.summary: Bird Alliance of Oregon issues a Lights Out alert for Friday, Sept. 19, 2025. 4.2 million birds are expected to be in the skies over Oregon during one night of peak migration season, which lasts through mid-October. The number of birds expected to fly over Oregon dips a bit Saturday to 3.1 million, but jumps again Sunday to more than 5 million.

articles.title: Purdue Study Reveals Why Some Hurricanes Rapidly Expand and Implications
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Researchers at Purdue University have discovered why some hurricanes expand dramatically while others remain relatively compact. They found that localized variations in sea surface temperatures act as a key driver in accelerating the growth of hurricane size. The research has significant implications for forecasting and risk management. The ability to predict when and where a hurricane might swell could revolutionize current warning systems and risk evaluations.

articles.title: NDP to ask for probe into alleged overspending on Saskatchewan firefighting planes
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: Frost Advisory from Friday 11:00 AM EDT until Saturday 9:00 am EDT. Volunteer firefighters from Davidson, Sask. load up their truck at the Provincial Wildfire Center in Prince Albert, Sask., on Wednesday, June 4, 2025. The Canadian Press has sponsored this article.

articles.title: Saskatchewan auditor to examine $187 million contract for firefighting planes
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: Frost Advisory from Friday 6:39 PM EDT until Saturday 9:00 AM EDT. Volunteer firefighters from Davidson, Sask., load up their truck at the Provincial Wildfire Center in Prince Albert, Sask. on Wednesday, June 4, 2025. The Canadian Press is the publisher of this article.

articles.title: Unstable water future: WMO report raises alarm
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: In 2024, two-thirds of the world's river basins saw abnormal conditions. The Amazon Basin and other parts of Africa were gripped by drought last year. Roughly 60% of rivers flow with either too much or too little water. UN Water estimates that 3.6 billion people globally experience water scarcity for at least one month a day.

articles.title: Ending corruption can build climate-resilient communities
articles.author: The Manila Times
articles.summary: The Philippines faces a daunting climate reality. Corruption is hamstrung the country's capacity to adapt and build resilience. Transparency International confirmed what many Filipinos already observe: the Philippines is corruption-ridden. The country is vulnerable to typhoons, rising seas and flooding.

articles.title: Complex puzzle: concessions needed for climate target
articles.author: Grace Crivellaro
articles.summary: Targets to reduce Australia's greenhouse gas emissions will require difficult trade-offs on the location of large renewable projects, experts warn. The targets will depend on where the projects are built, they say. It will be difficult to choose the best location for the projects.

articles.title: How climate change already impacts our daily lives
articles.summary: The impact of climate change and global warming is hitting humanity hard. It's also having grave implications for Earth's already fragile ecosystems. Click through for a real lesson on the consequences of global warming and climate change on everyday life and how to deal with it in everyday life.

articles.title: Climate Prudence vs. Climate Panic: DOE's Reality Check and Canada's EV Retreat
articles.author: The Epoch Times
articles.summary: The U.S. Department of Energy's July 29 report "A Critical Review of Impacts of Greenhouse Gas Emissions on the U.s. Climate" warrants careful attention. The report's conclusions challenge the prevailing climate orthodoxy, but it's written in a sober tone rather than alarmist rhetoric.

articles.title: ‘Heat touched every part of Canada': Why the 11th hottest summer on record is a warning sign of our changing climate
articles.author: Janis Ramsay
articles.summary: Extreme weather patterns seen in parts of Canada this summer were more likely thanks to human-caused climate change, Environment Canada announced this week. Experts shared their findings on the hot and dry weather experienced across the country with a summer 2025 online news conference on Sept. 17.

articles.title: Unexpected winter in Turkey: snow covers Rize district
articles.author: Eli Stoanova
articles.summary: The high mountain regions of Turkey's Rize district woke up under a blanket of snow. The most affected are the Avusor and Kavron plateaus in the Çamlıkhemşin municipality, where shepherds still live. The snow has affected livestock grazing and hastened preparations for their return to lower pastures.

articles.title: Minister reviews flood losses at Agriculture Commission meeting
articles.author: Urdu Point
articles.summary: Floods have caused irreparable losses to human lives, livestock, and crops. Punjab Agriculture Minister Ashiq Hussain Kirmani said on Friday that the recent floods have severely impacted the province's agricultural economy. He was presiding over a meeting of the Punjab Agricultural Council.

articles.title: Photos of Venezuelan fishing communities affected by US military strike
articles.author: Ariana Cubillos
articles.summary: Impoverished fishing communities on Venezuela's Paria Peninsula live on an idyllic stretch of Caribbean coast. The local fishing industry, which once offered jobs with living wages, has declined. Some fishing boats have been repurposed to smuggle migrants and traffic humans, wildlife and fuel.

articles.title: Rethinking Development: A Shift in Himachal Pradesh's Approach
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Himachal Pradesh's Chief Secretary Prabodh Saxena has called for a paradigm shift in addressing the state's developmental challenges. Saxena criticized the 'business as usual' mentality and urged for an approach that is holistic and inclusive. The committee discussed strategies for sustainable development, highlighting agriculture, water and forestry as interconnected sectors.

articles.title: Science Amplifies West African Farmers' Voices to Unlock Grouped Climate
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Farmers in West Africa rely on agriculture for their livelihoods, but they lack access to timely, actionable climate information that could transform their decision-making and resilience. A survey of over 1,200 farmers across Burkina Faso, Ghana, Mali, and Senegal found that only 10% of farmers consult scientific weather information and most rely on indigenous indicators.

articles.title: Can environmental law save the Earth?
articles.author: Amado Tolentino Jr.
articles.summary: The Paris Agreement committed countries to limiting the increase of global temperature to an average of 1.5 degrees Celsius. Developed and least developed countries must take action now, while advanced countries must fulfill their pledges. Collaborative action across government levels is an ongoing process.

articles.title: Ian McEwan's What We Can Know is like a game of two halves
articles.author: Rosemary Goring
articles.summary: What We Can Know is Ian McEwan's eighteenth novel. It is set in the year 2119, after the Inundation of 2042, in which more than 200 million people died. The narrator, Tom Metcalfe, is looking for a famous poem that Francis Blundy wrote for his wife Vivien's 54th birthday in 2014.

articles.title: Andy Harris serves Trump, not Eastern Shore
articles.author: Erin R. Flanagan
articles.summary: Maryland's Eastern Shore Regional Health has cut services in Chestertown and Dorchester County, forcing families to travel more than an hour for maternity or emergency care. Easton's Memorial Hospital has closed its obstetrics unit, leaving expectant mothers scrambling for options. There is no full-service VA hospital in the region. Rural Marylanders deserve a representative who fights for health care. Harris is silent as Trump guts the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and strips protections from the Chesapeake Bay.

articles.title: Terrifying study reveals exactly how many people DIED in Europe thanks to climate change this summer - including more than 1,000 in the UK
articles.author: Xantha Leatham
articles.summary: This summer was the UK's hottest on record. Global warming was responsible for more than 1,000 heat-related deaths in the UK alone. 68% of the 24,400 estimated heat deaths in Europe were caused by climate change this summer, according to experts.

articles.title: Wildfire warnings in B.C. as summer wraps up
articles.summary: B.C. is experiencing a longer wildfire season than previous years. Regan Hasegawa reports on why this is the case on CTV's "This is Life in B.C." today.   Â   .

articles.title: Understanding How Earth\u2019s Cycles Mirror Solar Variability
articles.author: Principia Scientific
articles.summary: changing weather patterns on planet Earth, he says. He suggests that changing weather pattern on Earth, for example, changing weather on Earth.   for me.  for the planet Earth's climate patterns.  For more information: ‘Warming weather patterns.

articles.title: Why won't Pacific nations lambast China on climate?
articles.author: Unconventional Economist
articles.summary: Low-lying Pacific Nations are angry at Australia over approval of Woodside's North West Shelf gas project extension. Anoteote is a low-lying island nation.    Anoteot is an island nation with a deep-water lagoon.

articles.title: Australia sacrifices self on climate altar
articles.author: Unconventional Economist
articles.summary: On Thursday, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese unveiled Labor's long-awaited 2035 climate targets. The targets promise to reduce emissions by reducing emissions by 20 per cent by the year 2035, according to the PM's office.    .

articles.title: London Fire Brigade: Busiest summer since 2022
articles.author: Harry Craig
articles.summary: The London Fire Brigade has had its busiest summer since the extreme heat of 2022. There were 83 wildfires in the capital between June and August, more than the summers of 2023 and 2024 combined. The most significant fire saw 25 fire engines and 125 firefighters called to a grass fire in Dagenham on 14 July, at the height of the third heatwave of the year. New equipment, improved training and prevention steps have helped to stop damage to properties, but climate change has increased the risk of wildfires.

articles.title: Crying Glacier
articles.author: Jason Kottke
articles.summary: A short documentary with the recorded sounds of a melting glacier gives an idea of what it sounds like inside a glacier. All these sounds are disappearing right now due to melting glaciers.   The problem is that nothing new is coming back and there is no new coming back.

articles.title: Michigan's bird migration is reaching its fall peak. How to track the travelers
articles.author: Jenna Prestininzi
articles.summary: Millions of Michigan's birds are heading south for the winter. The fall migration is reaching its peak time frame from mid-September to mid-October. BirdCast provides live and local bird migration alerts throughout the continental U.S. Ornithologists urge Americans to turn off nonessential lighting from 11 pm to 6 a.m. during peak migration periods.

articles.title: Playa del Carmen growth sparks warnings from scientists sparks warnings from scientists
articles.author: Ian Hayden Parker
articles.summary: Environmental groups say Playa del Carmen's growth is endangering dunes, mangroves, cenotes and nearby reefs. They are calling for changes to the city's PDU to address the problem now.   Â. Â

articles.title: Braised chicory stems with cannellini beans and bagna càuda
articles.summary: This time of year, most of the winter crops begin to bolt. The air temperature is getting warmer and the soil and ocean are still cool, but the sun is starting to become more imposing. It's throwing all its energy to the sky this time of the year.

articles.title: Climate change is an on-the-job hazard for these Inland Empire workers, report says
articles.author: Daily Bulletin
articles.summary: Inland Empire workers are facing an unprecedented cocktail of occupational hazards due to climate change, according to the report from UC Riverside's Inland Empire Labor and Community think tank. The report is based on projections for more frequent and intense heatwaves, wildfires, droughts and floods.

articles.title: Public meeting tackles growing crisis of collapsing oceanfront homes
articles.author: Joy Crist
articles.summary: Dare County officials, state and federal agencies, and coastal experts came together on Thursday, September 18, to address the problem of oceanfront homes collapsing into the Atlantic. The forum brought together an eight-member panel of scientists, stakeholders, emergency managers, and insurance specialists. Presentations covered shoreline science and the history of home collapses, followed by a wide-ranging Q&A where homeowners voiced frustration and made urgent appeals for help.

articles.title: Coastal Fear
articles.author: Madeline Fortson
articles.summary: Jacksonville's beaches are the heart of the community, but the coastline is disappearing. Storms hit harder each year, and the sand keeps washing away. The Florida Department of Environmental Protection says Duval County's shoreline is critically eroded after hurricanes Matthew, Irma and Ian. Jacksonville is creating an 'Adaptation Action Area' to help plan for climate change.

articles.title: Europe sees highest emissions from summer wildfires in 23 years
articles.author: Urdu Point
articles.summary: In 2025, Europe recorded the highest forest fire emissions since records began 23 years ago. Over the summer, there were intense forest fires in Europe, especially in the south of the continent. The emissions caused by these forest fires were the highest in at least 23 years.

articles.title: The Sun Is Way More Active Than Normal Right Now—and Nobody Knows Why
articles.author: Luis Prada
articles.summary: Solar Cycle 25 has been one of the most active on record. Scientists can't explain why. It might be tied to something called the Hale Cycle, a longer 22-year rhythm in which the sun's magnetic poles fully reverse. Space weather is going to remain intense and maybe become a little bit more so than the past few decades.

articles.title: Michael Smolens: California, San Diego lean in to nature-based coastal protections
articles.author: The San Diego Union-Tribune
articles.summary: From Sunset Cliffs to Oceanside, San Diego County is embarking on a sea change in efforts to protect the coast. The seawalls, jetties and rip-rap that have been deployed for generations to combat wind, wave and sea-level rise impacts are common features along the California coast.

articles.title: Partial solar eclipse to grace skies on September 21–22, not visible in Pakistan
articles.summary: The second solar eclipse of 2025 will occur on the night of September 21 and continue into September 22. The eclipse will not be visible in Pakistan. Instead, skywatchers in the Pacific Ocean, Atlantic Ocean, Antarctica, and Australia will be able to witness the celestial event.

articles.title: Climate change made heat waves this summer in Canada much more likely: Scientists
articles.author: Tiffany Crawford
articles.summary: This summer was Canada's 11th warmest on record, according to Environment and Climate Change Canada. There were heat waves in B.C., Alberta, the Northwest Territories, Quebec and Atlantic Canada. The most extreme event of the summer was in Atlantic Canada, which was at least 10 times more likely because of climate change.

articles.title: When does fall begin? Daylight saving time ends later in season
articles.author: Alexis Simmerman
articles.summary: This year, daylight saving time began on March 9 and will end on Sunday, Nov. 2. Time will fall back one hour from 2 a.m. to 1 am in the 48 states that observe it. This year the autumnal equinox is on Monday, Sept. 22.

articles.title: Global warming is upon us now
articles.author: Tricia Clarkson
articles.summary: According to the Weather Network, warm, dry conditions are expected to continue through to the end of September. Ashcroft, British Columbia experienced the hottest Sept. 3 on record with a temperature of 40.8 C. Recent studies have shown that recent heat waves were made significantly more likely by human-caused climate change.

articles.title: Decolonizing climate action
articles.author: Frey Blake-Pijogge
articles.summary: Labrador Inuit are experiencing climate change at a higher rate than in the south. Nunatsiavut Government is developing a strategy to mitigate climate change in Labrador and help Inuit adapt to the changing environment and conditions that are impacting their way of life.

articles.title: Decolonizing climate action
articles.author: Frey Blake-Pijogge
articles.summary: Labrador is experiencing climate change at a higher rate than in the south due to thawing permafrost, rapid sea ice changes, precipitation changes, sea level changes, and wildlife and vegetation changes due to climate change. In Nunatsiavut, the self-governing body for Labrador Inuit, the government has released its first climate plan in March. The strategy addresses climate change impacts and Inuit-led governance at its core.

articles.title: Night Recap - September 19, 2025
articles.author: The Standard 英文虎報
articles.summary: sugar as world gets hotter, according to a study by the American Institute of Health.    for more sugar.  for less sugar for more fat for more calories.  For more sugar for less fat for less calories. For more information, go to:

articles.title: Labor premieres the latest instalment in its predictable climate franchise
articles.author: Chris Uhlmann
articles.summary: The National Climate Risk Assessment was released this week. The report was presented in three plotlines: PG-rated version, MA (+1.5C of warming), MA (+2C) and the X-rated horror show (+3C). It was modelled against a pre-industrial nirvana, the era before electricity, modern medicine, hot running water and cars. There are more people dying from cold than from heat in Australia than from climate change.

articles.title: Climate change is an on-the-job hazard for these Inland Empire workers, report says
articles.author: Jeff Horseman
articles.summary: Inland Empire workers are at high risk of heatstroke and air pollution due to climate change, according to a new report from a UC Riverside think tank. More than two-thirds of climate-vulnerable workers in San Bernardino County and roughly one-third in Riverside County are Latino. California took steps in 2024 to lower indoor workplace temperatures.

articles.title: Climate change is an on-the-job hazard for these Inland Empire workers, report says
articles.author: Jeff Horseman
articles.summary: In the Inland Empire, climate change and poor air quality make it more dangerous for workers. About 18% of Inland workers are in climate-vulnerable occupations. More than two-thirds of workers in San Bernardino County and one-third in Riverside County are Latino. California is a leader in worker protection, but a more comprehensive approach is needed.

articles.title: Nigeria: Group Urges Government to Prioritize Climate Change in Budgets
articles.author: Chinedu Adonu
articles.summary: The South Saharan Social Development Organization (SSDO) has called on federal and state governments to prioritize climate change in their budgets. The appeal was made by SSDO's Head of Program, Udochukwu Egwim, during the Youth Climate Justice March in Enugu. The march was held in celebration of the 2025 Global Week for Action on Climate Justice, observed annually from September 15 to 21.

articles.title: Europe's summer heatwaves killed more than 16,000 people
articles.author: bne Intelli News
articles.summary: There were 16,266 heat-related deaths in Europe this summer due to extreme heatwaves. It was Europe's fourth-warmest summer on record. Europe remains the fastest-warming continent globally. Europe's Mediterranean region is a climate hotspot. Europe proposes to tap Russia's $300bn of frozen assets with Reparation Loans. Larsen & Toubro secures order for Kudankulam nuclear project in Tamil Nadu.

articles.title: El Nino's Hidden Impact: Intensifying India's Rainfall Extremes
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: El Nino suppresses monsoon rains in India's dry regions, but increases them in its wetter regions. Researchers from the City College of New York and Columbia University found a 50% increase in chances of heavy downpours during an El Nino.

articles.title: Vega Baja debates housing and environment
articles.author: Molly Grace
articles.summary: PSPV-PSOE is opening its political course in the Vega Baja region. The event is taking place across Guardamar del Segura and Torrevieja. The sessions focus on social and environmental priorities affecting the region, particularly in light of the DANA (Depresión Aislada en Niveles Altos) floods. The floods highlighted vulnerabilities in local infrastructure and housing, making disaster preparedness and climate resilience urgent priorities for local and regional policymakers.

articles.title: How the world's most elderly country is fighting heat in a deadly double crisis
articles.author: Jessie Yeung
articles.summary: This past summer has been Japan's hottest on record. In August, Japan recorded its highest-ever temperature at 41.8 degrees Celsius (107.24 degrees Fahrenheit). Between May and August, 90,000 people nationwide were taken to the hospital for heatstroke, some of whom needed to be hospitalized for weeks on end. The elderly don't feel the heat as much, have more difficulty regulating body temperature and don't notice thirst as easily.

articles.title: Study: Wildfire Smoke Already Kills 40,000 Americans a Year, With Deaths Projected to Top 70,000 by 2050
articles.summary: Wildfire smoke is responsible for over 40,000 deaths annually in the U.S. by mid-century, premature deaths from wildfire smoke could increase to as many as 71,000 per year due to worsening climate change. Total wildfire smoke pollution could reach 1.9 million from 2026 to 2055 if climate change continues unabated.

articles.title: Africa: Frontline of a Planetary Emergency - Africa Demands Climate Justice and Action
articles.author: Kizito Makoye
articles.summary: The State of Africa's Environment 2025 report was launched in Bole on September 18. Sunita Narain is the Director General of India's Centre for Science and Environment. Africa's warming trend now outpaces the global average. The report warns that Africa's climate crisis is not just about weather but about livelihoods.

articles.title: Floods force 100,000 out of their homes – and the water in this African city is still rising
articles.author: Sam Kiley
articles.summary: Lake Tanganyika is three metres higher than it was a decade ago. More than 100,000 people have lost their homes in Burundi to rising waters due to climate change. The lake is set to rise by a further two metres in the next 10 years. Donald Trump announced the end of global USAID funding in January 2025. USAID services have also been cut in the country.

articles.title: Group urges government to Prioritize climate change in budgets
articles.author: Chinedu Adonu
articles.summary: The South Saharan Social Development Organization (SSDO) has called on federal and state governments to prioritize climate change in their budgets to enable effective mitigation and adaptation measures. The appeal was made by SSDO's Head of Program, Udochukwu Egwim, during the Youth Climate Justice March in Enugu. The march was held in celebration of the 2025 Global Week for Action on Climate Justice, observed annually from September 15 to 21.

articles.title: Global rise in large-scale forest fires, study warns
articles.author: Catalan News
articles.summary: Large-scale forest fires have increased in frequency and severity over recent years, according to an international study by a researcher from Catalonia's Center for Ecological Research and Forestry Applications (CREAF). The study analyzed the tipping point in the acceleration of climate change.

articles.title: The ‘blob' is back — except this time it stretches across the entire North Pacific
articles.author: Andrew Freedman
articles.summary: A record-breaking and expansive marine heat wave is underway in the Pacific Ocean, stretching about 5,000 miles from the water around Japan to the West Coast of the United States. The sea surface temperature difference from average across the entire North Pacific smashed an all-time record for the month of August. It is part of a pattern of marine heat waves in this area following a severe heating event in 2013 that lasted until 2016.

articles.title: The ‘blob' is back — except this time it stretches across the entire North Pacific
articles.author: Andrew Freedman
articles.summary: A record-breaking and expansive marine heat wave is underway in the Pacific Ocean stretching from the water around Japan to the US West Coast. The abnormally warm 'blob' of ocean water is affecting the weather on land and could have ripple effects on marine life.

articles.title: NASA warns of solar storm chaos as sun's unexpected awakening threatens global blackouts
articles.author: Tags
articles.summary: NASA warns of solar storm chaos as sun's unexpected awakening threatens global blackouts. The sun has unexpectedly reversed a decades-long decline in activity, with NASA now warning of stronger solar winds, flares, and geomagnetic storms that threaten power grids, satellites, and GPS systems. The current solar cycle (25) has defied predictions, arriving earlier and stronger than expected, with peak activity forecasted between 2025 and 2026.

articles.title: Protecting our homes, roads and habitat – Save the date for sea-level rise workshops this fall
articles.author: The San Juan Journal
articles.summary: San Juan County is taking steps to better understand and plan for the future of sea-level rise in the islands, including mitigating the impact on public and private infrastructure. The County is planning a mitigation plan for sea-lighing rise in San Juan Islands.

articles.title: How climate change is altering this language
articles.summary: In the Sápmi region of the Arctic, climate change is changing daily life of Sámi people and their traditional language is suffering as a result. Check out the gallery to learn more about the situation in the region and the people affected by it.

articles.title: Scientists trace catastrophic heat waves to major fossil fuel producers in landmark attribution study
articles.summary: Fifty-five heat waves over the past quarter-century would not have happened without human-caused climate change, according to a study published on September 10 in the journal Nature. Global warming made all 213 of the heat waves examined more likely, the study found. Cement, oil and gas producers are responsible for 57% of all the carbon dioxide emitted from 1850 to 2023.

articles.title: Some NC Students Never Returned To School After Hurricane Helene
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: The hurricane hit North Carolina a year ago, and the homeless student population surged, doubling in some places and increasing fourfold in one county. More than 2,500 students were identified as homeless as a direct result of Hurricane Helene. The storm damaged more than 73,000 homes, knocked out electricity and water for weeks or even months, and closed schools for large stretches of time. The impact of the displacement lingers for the region's children.

articles.title: Research finds that Americans are turning to more sugar as the Earth gets hotter from climate change
articles.summary: When the temperature rises, Americans drink more sugary beverages and eat more frozen desserts. The amount of sugar the average American consumes goes up by about 0.4 grams per degree Fahrenheit per day. The United States' average annual temperature has gone up about 2.2 degrees since 1895. Just one added sugary soft drink per day increases diabetes risk by 29%.

articles.title: Weather Words: Intertropical Convergence Zone
articles.author: Jennifer Gray
articles.summary: The Intertropical Convergence Zone is a belt that circles the Earth near the equator. It is one of the planet's most active regions for rainfall. The ITCZ shifts north and south with the seasons. This seasonal migration plays a major role in tropical climate patterns, including wet and dry seasons and can even influence hurricane formation.

articles.title: Hurricane Helene hit North Carolina a year ago. Some students never returned to school
articles.summary: After Hurricane Helene, more than 2,500 students in western North Carolina lost their homes. The storm damaged more than 73,000 homes, knocked out electricity and water for weeks or months, closed schools for large stretches of time, and made it difficult for families to recover.

articles.title: 45 reported dead in south Punjab as 1,112 villages inundated: handout
articles.author: Aisha Sarwari
articles.summary: Floods in south Punjab have caused large-scale human and material losses, including 45 reported deaths. 1,174,870 people have been affected and 1,112 villages were inundated by floodwaters. Flooding also affected agricultural land and destroyed crops on 1,249,328 acres. Relief camps have been established in the flood-hit areas, providing food, medicine and other essential services.

articles.title: In 2050, I'll be 46. These climate targets abandon my generation
articles.author: Anjali Sharma
articles.summary: The old guard, the Coalition, didn't support the climate protest when it was happening in Melbourne in 2019. The opposition, the Labor government, was more welcoming and supported the climate movement. Now, the old guard has lost all hope and hope has been destroyed over the past week.

articles.title: In 2050, I'll be 46. These climate targets abandon my generation
articles.author: Anjali Sharma
articles.summary: The lower end of the climate change target is a dangerously weak commitment dressed up as courageous leadership. This past week could not be a clearer demonstration. For many people, the climate crisis is not about parties or politics, it's about survival. In 2050, I'll be 46 and I'll raise children in a world earmarked by increased heat-related deaths and sea levels rising. My mum will be 80 and she'll have constant asthma attacks.

articles.title: ‘Too late to avoid any impacts': The reality of Australia's climate crisis
articles.author: Sydney Morning Herald
articles.summary: Chris Bowen says climate change is here and it's not too late to avoid the worst of its effects. He is the minister for environment and climate change. He says it's important to prepare for the worst effects of climate change and prepare for it now.

articles.title: In 15 Years, 70% of Atlantic Coral Reefs Will Be Stagnant
articles.author: Arden Dier
articles.summary: Coral reefs in the Atlantic could stop growing and face near-total collapse by the end of the century if global temperatures keep climbing. If warming tops 2 degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels by century's end, 99% of Atlantic corals could fall victim to erosion.

articles.title: Athens among cities with rising heat deaths
articles.author: Yiannis Elafros
articles.summary: There were 808 heat-related deaths in Greece this summer, including 630 in Athens. Rome, Athens and Bucharest had the highest excess mortality rates among European capitals. In 14 Greek cities, the impact varied, with Patra recording 39 excess deaths and Katerini having the highest percentage of deaths linked to climate change.

articles.title: Why autumn leaves will be even more spectacular this year
articles.author: Shaheena Uddin
articles.summary: Autumn is known for its stunning display of orange and red hues. This year the leaves could be more vibrant than ever because of the warm and sunny summer. The cooler nights and shorter days on the way will trigger the change. Some trees such as horse chestnuts have already turned brown and dropped their leaves due to drought.

articles.title: Charleston's battle against 'Big Oil' sputters out behind closed doors after yearslong lawsuit
articles.author: Grace Beahm Alford/Staff
articles.summary: The city of Charleston tried to sue 24 oil companies for their alleged role in climate change-induced flooding in the city. In August, a judge threw out the city's 2020 suit against the oil companies. The corporations argued the city didn't have the legal grounds to bring the suit and only the federal government can regulate emissions. The city experienced 54 tidal floods last year. Charleston is feeling the heat of a warming world.

articles.title: Extreme weather in 2025 could cost the EU up to €126bn
articles.author: Pierre Pailler
articles.summary: Extreme weather events hit Europe hard in the summer of 2025, with heat waves, droughts and floods having serious consequences for the environment and health, as well as for the economy. The European Union is set to lose €43 billion in gross value added (GVA) in 2025, equivalent to 0.26% of its total output, as a result of the meteorological events. Droughts have the greatest economic impact, with losses of nearly €30 billion for the EU in 2025. Spain will deal with estimated losses of €10.7 billion in 2025 (€27.6 billion by 2029), Italy €6.8 billion (€17.5 billion by

articles.title: Buffalo Tests its Status as a Climate Refuge
articles.author: Finya Swai
articles.summary: Darnel Davila and his family came to Buffalo after Hurricane Maria devastated his hometown of Loiza, Puerto Rico. He is now fluent in English and a lead bomba drummer at El Batey, a local Puerto Rican cultural center. Puerto Ricans make up 74 percent of Buffalo's Latino and Hispanic population. According to census data, Buffalo saw an increase of roughly 6,000 Puerto Rican immigrants between 2015 and 2019.

articles.title: Bad sign for birds; UK's early ripening berries
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: There is a bumper gin crop in the UK. This year hawthorn trees are producing their sloe berries earlier than usual. Blackthorns are appearing a month earlier than scheduled. This is bad news for migratory birds like redwings and fieldfares.

articles.title: If you can't stand the heat, get out the ire
articles.summary: Labor's proposed 62 to 70 per cent emissions reduction by 2035 is timid and unsafe for everyday Australians. It falls short of the Climate Change Authority's advised range of 65 to 75 per cent. The way forward is to aim for the upper end of the target, not the lower.

articles.title: Protecting our homes, roads and habitat – Save the date for sea-level rise workshops this fall
articles.summary: San Juan County is planning a series of community workshops to share information about sea-level rise and solicit feedback from community members. The first workshop will focus on the big picture, reviewing the science and how the County can expect to be affected in the next 20-50 years. The second workshop will dive into island-specific case studies that illustrate potential responses for both public assets and private assets.

articles.title: Refreezing poles: can it reverse global warming?
articles.summary: 750 billion tons of ice is melting every year due to climate change and global warming. Sea ice around Antarctica shrank to the smallest area ever recorded in early 2022. Scientists are looking to develop a radical method to reverse global warming: refreezing of the North and South Poles.

articles.title: Can a law bring about change? The global climate crisis and national climate laws
articles.author: Antrea Panagiotou
articles.summary: Cyprus needs a National Climate Law to be on track for climate neutrality. 22 European countries have already enacted similar laws. The European Climate Law implements the European Green Deal by committing all Member States to achieve climate neutrality by 2050 and reduce GHG emissions by 55% by 2030.

articles.title: 'Unliveable': sobering climate change warning for north
articles.summary: Parts of northern Australia will be unliveable within decades if more is not done to cut carbon emissions, an environmental conference has been told. The first National Climate Risk Assessment painted a catastrophic vision of Australia's future if global warming goes unchecked. The federal government's 2035 climate target aims to bring emissions down by between 62 and 70 per cent in the next decade based on 2005 levels. Dr Howey is disappointed with the Albanese government's target.

articles.title: 'Unliveable': sobering climate change warning for north
articles.author: AAP Newswire
articles.summary: Parts of northern Australia will be unliveable within decades if more is not done to cut carbon emissions, an environmental conference has been told. The conference is taking place in Melbourne.       "Carbon emissions are the main cause of climate change".

articles.title: ‘We are full': Australian population debate needed as housing crisis worsens
articles.summary: Sky News host Danica De Giorgio discusses mass migration in Australia following widespread protests around the country. She claims housing affordability is at its worst in more than two decades, building approvals are at decade lows, too many Aussies cannot afford to buy a home, and incomes are going backwards.

articles.title: Incredible destinations where the sun shines all night
articles.summary: There are places on Earth where the summer sun never actually sets and can be seen in the sky at all times. Even though these places see an abundance of daylight on summer days, they can get quite cold. Click through the gallery to find the famed midnight sun.

articles.title: 🌱 Patch AM: Join the forum tackling coastal issues in Wilmington
articles.author: Patch AM Team
articles.summary: The Coastal Society is hosting a forum on coastal issues at UNCW's Discovery Hall. A Miracle League player from Wilmington has been selected for the 2025 All-Star game in St. Louis. The New Hanover County School Board holds a work session to discuss the future of NHHS in Wilmington. The City of Wilmington confirms that former Confederate statues have been relocated to Davidson County. Damion Murrill is a Grammy-nominated artist from Wilmington.

articles.title: ‘Crisis of justice' as floods devastate: Pakistan's climate change minister
articles.summary: Pakistan is reeling from one of the worst floods in decades. More than 1,000 people have been killed and more than 6 million people affected. Climate change is seen as one of several factors contributing to the deluge. Pakistan's climate change minister questions the 'lopsided allocation' of funding to fight the impact of climate change.

articles.title: 150 hills at risk: Separate survey needed for conservation
articles.author: Editorial Desk
articles.summary: Globally, Bangladesh ranks second in terms of temperature rise. Due to heat, the country is incurring damages worth nearly 210 billion taka. About 150 hills in Chattogram city, Hathazari, and Sitakunda are at risk of vanishing due to land ministry surveys.

articles.title: New report warns of escalating climate and environmental disasters in Africa
articles.summary: A new report by Centre for Science and Environment (CSE) in India has painted an alarming picture of Africa's climate and environmental future. Since 2021, more than 41,500 deaths have been recorded, while droughts alone have devastated 178 million lives. Nearly 265 million people were forced into internal migration in the past year alone, and projections show up to 5 per cent of African population could become environmental migrants by 2050.

articles.title: Climate change could displace 100 million Africans by 2050
articles.summary: By 2050, up to 5% of Africa's population could be forced to move due to the impacts of climate change. Africa's seven largest coastal cities are projected to grow by 40% between 2020 and 2030, and Port Harcourt, Nigeria, could grow by 53%. Cocoa production in West and Central Africa supplies 70% of the world's cocoa is under threat.

articles.title: Heatwaves, rising temperatures behind 16,500 deaths across European cities
articles.author: Aryan Rai
articles.summary: Scientists estimate that 16,500 people died in Europe this summer due to the rising temperatures due to climate change. The summer of 2025 was Europe's fourth-hottest recorded summer. Rome had the highest number of estimated deaths. Athens and Paris followed with 630 and 409.

articles.title: NiMet, C-WINS Join Forces To Advance Climate Action
articles.author: Chukwu David
articles.summary: NiMet and C-WINS have struck a partnership aimed at advancing climate action in Nigeria. The partnership will focus on developing localised early-warning systems for farmers and rolling out community workshops on climate-smart agriculture. It will also provide real-time climate data to improve food production and reduce climate-related health risks.

articles.title: Earth's water system is spiralling with deadly swings between too little and too much, warns WMO
articles.author: Euronews Green
articles.summary: The world's water cycle is becoming erratic, swinging between destructive floods and drought, according to a new report from the World Meteorological Organization (WMO). For the third year in a row, every glacier region reported a loss of ice. In Africa's tropical zone, unusually heavy rainfall in 2024 resulted in around 2,500 deaths and 4 million people displaced. In Asia and the Pacific, record-breaking rainfall and tropical cyclones resulted in more than 1,000 fatalities. Brazil saw simultaneous extremes as catastrophic flooding in the south of the country killed 183 people. The Amazon Basin and other parts of Africa were gripped by severe drought in 2024.

articles.title: Wildfire Smoke Could Cause 1.4 Million Deaths a Year by 2100, Experts Say
articles.author: Ishwi Singh
articles.summary: Wildfire smoke could cause 1.4 million deaths annually by 2100 due to climate change. Vulnerable regions like sub-Saharan Africa face the greatest risks. Iswi Singh is a content writer with a background in English literature. She worked as an editorial intern at Oxford University Press.

articles.title: Life in a ‘sinking nation': Tuvalu's dreams of dry land
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: With sea levels rising, many people face the prospect that their homes may soon cease to exist, and they don't know where they are going to move to.    - The author's article is based on a report by the International Institute of Public Policy.

articles.title: Climate Change Vulnerability Among Farmers in Can Tho
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: In the Vietnamese Mekong River Delta, climate change threatens farmers' livelihoods. The study identifies key factors that influence how vulnerable farmers are to climate change. It emphasizes the importance of agricultural education and awareness programs to empower farmers. It also highlights the significance of social networks in building resilience among farming communities.

articles.title: Environment: Your heart will thank you, and so will the animals
articles.author: Karine Nohr
articles.summary: Sheffield Foodworks in Upperthorpe, Sharrow and Handsworth can provide healthy and cheap food. The online Sheffield Directory offers free courses across the City in a 'family programme' that will address healthy eating. The meat industry is one of the biggest contributors to the climate emergency. Cutting down the amount of meat in your diet is good for your health and wallet.

articles.title: Vietnam requires up to US$92 billion for climate adaptation by 2030
articles.summary: Vietnam will need an estimated US$55-92 billion between 2021 and 2030 to implement its climate adaptation tasks. Vietnam is among 65 countries that have submitted their updated NAPs to the Secretariat of the UNFCCC. The report stresses Vietnam's vulnerability due to its long coastline, thousands of offshore islands and two densely populated deltas.

articles.title: ‘Crisis of justice' as floods devastate: Pakistan's climate change minister
articles.summary: Pakistan ranks among top 10 most climate-vulnerable nations but contributes less than 1 percent of global emissions. Pakistan's climate change minister is worried about the floods that have devastated the country's coast.      Â   .   in Pakistan

articles.title: Climate Threatens Rangelands More Than Herd Size
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Cornell researchers used detailed data from Mongolia to study rangeland degradation. They found that climate change is a bigger factor than overgrazing. They urge policymakers to focus more on global mitigation and less on taxing herders in a nation that contributes little to global greenhouse gas emissions.

articles.title: Mozambique: U.S. Govt Promises to Continue Aid From Mozambique Challenge Corporation
articles.summary: Millennium Challenge Corporation (MCC) will disbursed the foreign aid promised to Mozambique under the Compact for the Connectivity and Coastal Resilience. The total investment is valued at 537 million US dollars. MCC is an independent US government agency working to reduce global poverty through economic growth.

articles.title: Boosting Wildlife Health To Prepare For H5 Bird Flu
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The global spread of H5 avian influenza (bird flu) is a serious threat to our native species. If it reaches Australia, it could affect many birds and even some mammals. We can take steps now to prepare for H5 bird flu. Here are 5 easy ways you can help.

articles.title: Africa-EU Forum in Nairobi Urges Adoption of Science and Innovation for Green Transition
articles.author: Bruhan Makong
articles.summary: Policymakers, researchers, donors, regional institutions, civil society, and private sector representatives from Africa and Europe are meeting in Nairobi this week for the annual Africa Regional Centres of Excellence (ArcX) Forum. The conference is focused on how science, technology, and innovation can accelerate Africa's green transition and sustainable development. It is pushing for evidence-based policymaking, stronger research collaboration, and knowledge sharing to enhance the management of Africa's forests, biodiversity and ecosystems.

articles.title: Pakistan's climate change minister lashes out at US, ‘crisis of justice'
articles.author: Faras Ghani
articles.summary: Pakistan has been hit by heavy rains and flooding since June 26. More than 1,000 people have been killed and more than 2 million displaced. Climate change is seen as one of the several factors contributing to the deluge. Pakistan ranks among the top 10 most climate-vulnerable nations, but it contributes less than 1 percent of global emissions. Pakistan's climate change minister questions the 'lopsided allocation' of funding to fight climate change.

articles.title: ‘Crisis of justice' as floods devastate: Pakistan's climate change minister
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Flooding in Pakistan has killed more than 1,000 people and displaced more than 2 million since June 26. More than 12,500 houses have been damaged, 6,500 livestock lost and crops destroyed. Climate change is seen as one of the several factors contributing to the deluge. Pakistan's climate change minister has slammed the 'crisis of justice' facing his country.

articles.title: Australia's National Climate Risk Assessment
articles.summary: A digital story about Australia's National Climate Risk Assessment did not mention the timeframe for some of the climate scenarios it mentioned. Additional information was added to the story for clarity. It was not clear what the timeframe was for some climate scenarios mentioned in the story.

articles.title: Moroccan city struggles with sand encroachment
articles.author: Africanews
articles.summary: The city of Essaouira on Morocco's Atlantic coast is experiencing an escalating problem of sand encroachment. Many homes have become engulfed by sand dunes, with fears of a potential disaster growing. Morocco has seen extreme weather events such as droughts and floods recently.

articles.title: Water impacted in climate report
articles.author: McPherson Media Group
articles.summary: The release of the National Climate Risk Assessment and National Adaptation Plan exposes the risks to Australia's agriculture sector from climate change, particularly water security for irrigation to grow food and fibre, according to a national water body. The report was prepared by the Australian National Water Authority.

articles.title: How Labor's new climate plan will change your life
articles.author: Ryan Cropp
articles.summary: Labor's new emissions plans are set to change the energy transition for most Australians. It's not had a major effect on everyday lives so far, but that's going to change under Labor's new plans. It will affect people's lives in a big way.

articles.title: Kerry County Council taking action on climate change
articles.author: Alastair Tibbs
articles.summary: Kerry's Community Climate Innovation Programme is free of charge and will run over the next three months. The first gathering took place at the Tralee Bay Wetlands Centre on Wednesday. The programme has already been piloted at Laois County Council and now Kerry joins Meath, Waterford, South Dublin and Wicklow councils in expanding the scheme.

articles.title: Study presents modeled views of Ocracoke highway's future
articles.author: Catherine Kozak
articles.summary: Ocracoke Island's future is threatened by sea level rise and climate change. Researchers met with islanders to present a study that modeled what the island's future may hold under different scenarios. The study was led by UNC Chapel Hill researchers and included scientists from N.C. State University, Duke University, East Carolina University, National Park Service and Hyde County.

articles.title: Sweden to Miss EU as Well as National Climate Goals
articles.author: The Local
articles.summary: Sweden is set to miss EU's 2030 climate goals by 4.3 million tons of carbon dioxide, according to the government's own figures. The opposition describes the poor progress on climate as 'a betrayal of all Swedes'.   .

articles.title: Australia Exposes a Massive $600 Billion Loss
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: The impacts of climate change could strip a staggering $600 billion from Australia's property market by 2050. The federal government's first National Climate Risk Assessment highlights the threat of rising sea levels, escalating bushfires, destructive floods, and severe storms. Despite the warning, Aussie buyers continue to flock to high-risk areas.

articles.title: Floods, bushfires and rising sea levels: The $600billion property wipeout set to impact millions of Aussies by 2050
articles.author: NICHOLAS COMINO
articles.summary: The impacts of climate change could strip a staggering $600billion from Australia's property market by 2050, according to the National Climate Risk Assessment. Despite the warning, Aussie buyers continue to flock to high-risk areas, despite the warnings. The trend is mirrored across the east coast, where towns like Palmers Island, Crangan Bay, East Wardell, Seahampton, and Bucketty in NSW continue to attract buyers.

articles.title: Scientists to research bird flu on Antarctic islands
articles.author: Grace Crivellaro
articles.summary: Australian scientists will set sail on a 10-day expedition to the Heard and McDonald islands, 4000 kms southwest of Western Australia, to study whether bird flu has reached the World Heritage-listed islands. Environment Minister Murray Watt said Australia is the only continent remaining free of the h5 strain of bird flu, despite it having spread globally. The expedition is expected to be wet, wild and windy.

articles.title: Scientists to research bird flu on Antarctic islands
articles.author: Grace Crivellaro
articles.summary: A group of experts will voyage to Heard and McDonald islands, 4000 kms southwest of Western Australia, as part of the nation's biggest campaign to the area in two decades. They will study whether bird flu has reached the World Heritage-listed islands. Environment Minister Murray Watt joined the scientists in Hobart on Friday. The expedition is expected to be wet, wild and windy, but RSV Nuyina icebreaking ship is "cozy" and biosecurity risks will be mitigated.

articles.title: Scientists to research bird flu on Antarctic islands
articles.author: Grace Crivellaro
articles.summary: Australian scientists will set sail on a wet, wild and windy expedition to research whether bird flu has reached World Heritage-listed islands in Antarctica. The expedition will take place in the middle of the wet, wet weather. It will be very windy and wet.

articles.title: Labor's Low Target Ignores Fire, Flood, Heat Costs
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Minister Bowen said today that a target over 70% would carry unacceptable environmental, social and economic costs for Australia. The modelling he is relying on does not factor in the costs of climate impacts from the Government's own National Climate Risk Assessment. Greens Senator Larissa Waters says the target was crafted to appease the coal and gas industry. She also criticises Labor's cynical attempt to mislead the public on the ambition of their climate targets.

articles.title: Child Rights Groups Urge Bold 2035 Climate Goals
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Save the Children Australia, Plan International Australia and UNICEF call on the Australian government to adopt strong emissions targets that aim to limit global warming to 1.5°C. Pacific communities are facing some of the worst impacts of climate change despite contributing just 0.02% of global emissions. Half of Pacific girls surveyed say climate disasters have kept them from going to school and 50% say the biggest impact is lack of clean water.

articles.title: Why won't Pacific nations lambast China on climate?
articles.author: Leith van Onselen
articles.summary: Anote Tong, who led Kiribati between 2003 and 2016, accused Labor of putting economic interest before the security of important allies in the region by approving the extension. He said it would contribute to climate change and called into question Australia's sincerity in the relationship with the Pacific.

articles.title: Outer Canberra Most Unprepared For Climate Disaster
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Canberrans will face catastrophic impacts from climate change. Outer suburbs like West Belconnen, lower Woden, outer Gungahlin, and large parts of Tuggeranong are most at risk. The federal Labor government has announced a 2035 emissions reduction target of 62-70%.

articles.title: BOI secures Adaptation Fund's mandate to drive Nigeria's climate action
articles.author: Amos
articles.summary: The Bank of Industry (BOI) has been accredited by the Adaptation Fund as the implementation entity of climate-related development in Nigeria. Climate change presents many challenges for Nigeria, impacting many sectors and exacerbating existing vulnerabilities. Since 2010, the Fund has committed $1.25 billion for climate change adaptation and resilience projects and programmes.

articles.title: How climate change is affecting our homes
articles.author: Ang Li
articles.summary: This year, extreme heat in Europe killed roughly 2,300 people, severe flooding on the New South Wales coast left more than 48,000 stranded, and wildfires in Los Angeles destroyed at least 16,000 homes and other buildings. Poor housing can leave us more vulnerable to the effects of climate change. Australia's first National Climate Risk Assessment estimates 8.7% of residential buildings are in very high-risk areas. This proportion is projected to increase to 13.5% by 2090 in a scenario with a high global warming level.

articles.title: FAO warns The Bay's fishers of climate risks
articles.author: Dtnext Bureau
articles.summary: Small-scale fishers in the Bay of Bengal are losing their livelihoods due to rising climate risks. Climate-related storms are cutting 10-15 fishing days annually, affecting both income and food security of coastal households. Marine heatwaves are projected to reach up to 250 days annually by the end of the century. Poor access to insurance and limited safety compliance have increased fisherfolk's vulnerability to accidents and fatalities.

articles.title: Climate change causing havoc with global water cycle: UN
articles.author: NEWS WIRE
articles.summary: Climate change is spurring erratic and extreme swings between deluge and drought globally. Last year was the hottest on record, leading to prolonged droughts in northern parts of South America, the Amazon Basin and southern Africa. Europe saw its most extensive flooding in more than a decade. Africa's tropical zone experienced unusually heavy rainfall in 2024, resulting in around 2,500 deaths and displacing 4 million people. Asia and the Pacific were hit by record-breaking rainfall and tropical cyclones.

articles.title: Learn from climate emergencies
articles.author: Zile Huma
articles.summary: Nearly 900 people died and more than 1000 were injured from June 26 to August 22, 2025 due to floods in Pakistan. Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Punjab, Sindh, Balochistan, Islamabad, Gilgit-Baltistan, Azad Jammu and Kashmir, and Swat are the worst affected. Islamic Relief's emergency response team reports a massive scale of destruction in flood-hit parts of north-western Pakistan. Pakistan's contribution to global carbon emissions is less than one per cent, but it is declared among the top ten countries most affected by climate change. Developed nations continue to promote their economic interests at the expense of the Global South.

articles.title: Why adaptation finance cannot wait
articles.author: Jawad Khalid
articles.summary: This summer's floods in Punjab displaced more than 2 million people and killed hundreds. Flooding and sea-level rise could displace 400 million people across Pakistan, including 320 million in Punjab. According to the UK's Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office, Pakistan needs $348 billion between 2023 and 2030 to cope with climate impacts. Current spending on adaptation amounts to just 6.0% of what is required, a gap 16 times larger than existing flows.

articles.title: Crisis or hoax?, a new book by former Dutch parliamentarian
articles.author: Anthony Watts
articles.summary: In Crisis or Hoax? Jules de Waart critically examines the IPCC's CO2-driven climate change narrative. He is an earth scientist by training and a former politician. He served for many years in the Provincial States of North Holland and in the Dutch National Parliament. After leaving Parliament he worked as an interim manager on projects related to infrastructure and the environment. He studied physical geography and climatology at the University of Amsterdam and earned his PhD.

articles.title: North Carolina students displaced by Hurricane Helene confront a year of uncertainty and upheaval
articles.author: TOI Education
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene devastated western North Carolina a year ago. Over 2,500 students were homeless directly because of the storm and many families were displaced. The long-term impact on learning, well-being, and sense of security continues to ripple through communities.

articles.title: Climate change protesters block off major Melbourne bridge - causing traffic delays across the city ...
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: Climate change protesters blocked Punt Road over the Yarra River Bridge between Alexandra and Melbourne's northbound lanes. Melbourne motorists face a nightmare commute into work.   Â      in the northbound lane of the road is blocked, in the southbound lane.

articles.title: Australia must prepare for future without coal, climate agency chief says
articles.summary: Australia must prepare for a future without coal, climate agency chief says. The agency chief is responsible for Australia's climate change policy. The government is concerned about the impact of climate change on Australia's energy supply.      Â   y

articles.title: Portugal endures one of hottest, driest Augusts in decades
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Portugal experienced one of the hottest and driest Augusts in decades. The average air temperature reached 24.4 degrees Celsius, 1.49 degrees Celsius above the 1991-2020 normal. The report warned of a sharp expansion of meteorological drought affecting almost the entire mainland territory.

articles.title: Horn of Africa forecast to experience dry weather until December
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: The Horn of Africa is forecast to experience drier-than-usual conditions from October to December. The dry conditions are expected to affect food security in the region, where 72 million people are food insecure. The highest probabilities are over parts of Kenya, Ethiopia, Djibouti, Somalia, and Tanzania.

articles.title: Floods, bushfires and rising sea levels: The $600billion property wipeout set to impact millions of ...
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: The impacts of climate change could strip a staggering $600billion from Australia's property market by 2050. The federal government's first National Climate Risk Assessment paints a stark picture for homeowners in high-risk areas. The report warned rising sea levels could be the biggest threat to property prices.

articles.title: Most Caribbean coral reefs to stop growing by 2040, study warns
articles.author: Mongabay
articles.summary: Most coral reefs in the Caribbean could stop growing and start eroding by 2040 if global warming continues unchecked. Coral reefs protect valuable coastlines from flooding during cyclones and storm surges by breaking up wave energy. For the reefs to continue to act as they should, they need to be protected.

articles.title: Is Europe winter-ready despite lower gas stocks?
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Autumn's chill is creeping in across much of Europe, hinting at the deep freeze to come this winter. It's cold in Europe now, but it will get colder in the winter.   in the coming days. It will be colder in Europe.

articles.title: Assessing the Labour Market Impact of the Green Transition in Ireland (Department of Finance of Ireland)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: ESRI Working Paper No. 809 September 2025 assesses the labour market impact of the green transition in Ireland. It is an unrefereed work-in-progress by researchers who are solely responsible for its development. It was written by Seamus McGuinness, Elisa Staffa, Eimear Flynn, and Paul Redmond.

articles.title: UN chief warns 1.5C warming goal at risk of ‘collapsing'
articles.author: CTV
articles.summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said efforts to cap climate are a good step. He told AFP on Friday that the UN is committed to this cause.    for the future of the planet. for the UN's future on climate change.  for AFP.

articles.title: New Brunswick releases report on one of the province's biggest historic fires
articles.author: CTV
articles.summary: The fire on Oldfield Road in Miramichi started on August 6 and grew to more than 1,400 hectares. It's burning since then and is not under control.    -   for the time being, it's burning in the area of Oldfield Rd.

articles.title: In 2050, I'll be 46. These climate targets abandon my generation
articles.author: Sydney Morning Herald
articles.summary: Australia has said it will cut emissions by 62 to 70 per cent. This is not enough to save my parents, let alone me.   iReport.com will let you know if you want to get involved in the conversation. Please contact iReport on 020 3615 909090.

articles.title: Venezuela Fishing Community
articles.author: Beaumont Enterprise
articles.summary: A woman hangs clothes to dry in the fishing community of El Morro de Puerto Santo, on Venezuela's Paria Peninsula, on Sunday, Sept. 14, 2025, in Venezuela's paria peninsula.    i.e. in the area where she lives.

articles.title: Stormy September surrenders to sunny La Ni�a summer start, says scientist
articles.author: RNZ
articles.summary: New Zealand can expect a bumpy ride through September storms before conditions calm down as October settles. La Niña is a climate pattern driven by cooler-than-usual ocean temperatures along the equator. It is returning for the fifth time in the last five years.

articles.title: Gabrielle Poised To Become 2nd Hurricane Of The Atlantic Season
articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Gabrielle is expected to become a hurricane this weekend. Who will be impacted by the storm?   Â. Â   yestardiaforecast.com.  yestdiaforecasts.com

articles.title: Coalition Urges Cities Urges To Tackle Climate-Related Health Threats
articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: A new report warns cities are at the forefront of a global health crisis exacerbated by climate change. It calls for a reimagined approach to health in cities and a rethinking of the current approach to public health in the cities. The report is titled "Cities at the Forefront of a Global Health Crisis".

articles.title: Satellite Images Reveal New Island in Alaska National Park
articles.author: Newsweek
articles.summary: The formation of the island is a concern to experts. It highlights the issue of glacier retreat caused by climate change, they say. It's a concern for the broader issue of climate change and glacier retreat. It is a cause of concern for many people.

articles.title: The ‘blob' is back — except this time it stretches across the entire North Pacific
articles.author: system
articles.summary: A record-breaking marine heat wave is underway in the Pacific Ocean, stretching about 5,000 miles from the water around Japan to the West Coast of the United States. The abnormally warm ocean water is getting a boost from human-caused global warming. There have been multiple die-offs of marine mammals, seabirds and forage fish in Alaskan waters this summer.

articles.title: Not content with showing his incompetence about the existence of batteries for renewable energy, the Energy Secretary tries to lie about climate change
articles.author: Evil Mackerel
articles.summary: This year there was more ice in the Arctic than 10 years ago. Aerial photos of Bear Glacier taken from the same location on October 2012 and September 2019 show that Bear Glacier is shrinking in size. The glacier is shrinking at the same rate as it did in 2012.

articles.title: A walk across Alaska's Arctic sea ice brings to life the losses that appear in climate data
articles.author: Alexandra Jahn
articles.summary: Alexandra Jahn has been working with data from satellites and climate models. The Arctic sea ice cover has decreased by 50% from 1979 to 2024. This decline of summer sea ice area has a multitude of effects. For people living along the Arctic Ocean coast in Alaska, winter sea ice will still return for now, if global greenhouse gas emissions are not reduced.
